title: Quotation of the Day: Pipeline Hack Reveals Seams in Nation’s Cybersecurity Armor
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 15, 2021.
content: “It’s all fun and games when we are stealing each other’s money. When we are messing with a society’s ability to operate, we can’t tolerate it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: Violence in an Israeli town carries bitter echoes of 1948 for Palestinians.
description: On the afternoon of July 11, 1948, Israeli regiments conducted an operation in the town of Lydda that became formative to their new state, and echoes in the violence raging this week in that same town, now known as Lod.
content: On the afternoon of July 11, 1948, Israeli regiments conducted an operation in the town of Lydda that became formative to their new state, and echoes in the violence raging this week in that same town, now known as Lod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Kahneman, Olivier Sibony and Cass R. Sunstein
title: Bias Is a Big Problem. But So Is ‘Noise.’
description: When it comes to mistaken judgments, there is more than one kind of error.
content: The word “bias” commonly appears in conversations about mistaken judgments and unfortunate decisions. We use it when there is discrimination, for instance against women or in favor of Ivy League graduates. But the meaning of the word is broader: A bias is any predictable error that inclines your judgment in a particular direction. For instance, we speak of bias when forecasts of sales are consistently optimistic or investment decisions overly cautious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greek Neo-Nazi, a Member of Europe’s Parliament, Sent to Prison
description: Ioannis Lagos was a leading member of the extreme-right and now-defunct Golden Dawn, which rose to prominence in Greece’s Parliament in 2012 at the peak of the country’s financial crisis.
content: ATHENS — A convicted Greek neo-Nazi and member of the European Parliament was extradited back to Greece on Saturday to serve a 13-year prison term for his part in running the criminal organization Golden Dawn, once Greece’s third-largest political party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: N.Y.C. Pride Will Take Steps to Keep Police Out of Parade and Events
description: L.G.B.T.Q. police officers will not be allowed to participate as a group in the annual march, and organizers said they will rely on private security for their events.
content: New York City’s annual Pride celebration, which began 51 years ago as a defiant commemoration of an anti-police uprising and has evolved into a city-sanctioned equality jamboree, will take steps to reduce the presence of law enforcement at its events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Barbara Stone, Modeling Agent to American Beauties, Dies at 87
description: At Stewart Models in the 1960s and ’70s, she specialized in fresh-faced American blondes and played a key role in the careers of Cheryl Tiegs and Cybill Shepherd.
content: Barbara Stone, who as an agent nurtured models including Cheryl Tiegs, Cybill Shepherd and a young Martha Stewart, died on April 26 at a hospital in Roslyn, N.Y., on Long Island. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: Andrew J. Ries disarms us with an inventive variety crossword.
content: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS — Everyone who enjoys Thursday themes and Saturday puns in daily puzzles should be delving into Sunday variety puzzles, especially cryptic crosswords and puns and anagrams, or “Pandas.” This grid is a perfect example: It’s by a reliably excellent constructor of daily puzzles, and it’s full of inventive wordplay draped on a structure of anagrams that helps us fill in the blanks on the really tough stuff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Locks You Pick?
description: Sam Trabucco throws away the key to his cracking Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This themeless grid from Sam Trabucco feels as if it has an unexpected twist on every row and column, like a house of mirrors. I felt like that, anyway — a lot of funny surprises and connections, including that particular variety of pun where once you get it you wonder why you didn’t see it sooner, or how your mind ever led you astray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: The Assorted Teachings of Dogecoin
description: Created as a cryptocurrency parody in 2013, Dogecoin languished for years. Then, in 2021, it went absolutely wild. What have its holders learned?
content: In 2013, two friends who met in a chat room created Dogecoin as a joke. Named after a meme of an expressive dog, it was meant to mock the self-serious cryptocurrencies of the time, many of which never took off. The joke did, though, and it spawned a community of enthusiasts who kept it alive for years — at a negligible price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: After Years of Quiet, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict Exploded. Why Now?
description: A little-noticed police action in Jerusalem last month was one of several incidents that led to the current crisis.
content: JERUSALEM — Twenty-seven days before the first rocket was fired from Gaza this week, a squad of Israeli police officers entered the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem, brushed the Palestinian attendants aside and strode across its vast limestone courtyard. Then they cut the cables to the loudspeakers that broadcast prayers to the faithful from four medieval minarets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Klein
title: Daniel Patrick Moynihan Was Often Right. Joe Klein on Why It Still Matters.
description: How a politician who died in 2003 continues to dominate much of today’s political discussion.
content: “The central conservative truth is that it is culture, not politics, that determines the success of a society,” Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York said during a lecture at Harvard in 1986. “The central liberal truth is that politics can change a culture and save it from itself.” Moynihan, an apostle of complexity, lived at the intersection of those two truths, a place where he was free to become one of the most creative American thinkers of the late 20th century. He sensed, and then came to know, that the social problems of what was being called “postindustrial” society would be different from those that came before. He identified these problems, sometimes controversially. In so doing, he predicted the dislocations of the 21st century with uncanny accuracy. He did it with elegance and wit and — this may be a surprise — transcendent humility. His spot-on sense of what truly mattered deserves to be revisited now, if we’re to grope our way past the mess we’ve become as a society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Nurses’ union condemns C.D.C.’s new mask advice for vaccinated people.
description: The union of registered nurses called on the federal agency to revise its guidance, saying that “lives are in the balance.”
content: The nation’s largest union of registered nurses condemned the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Saturday for lifting mask recommendations for vaccinated people and called on the agency to “do the right thing” and revise its guidance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Wild Horses Adopted Under a Federal Program Are Going to Slaughter
description: Records show that some people who are paid $1,000 a head by the government to give legally protected mustangs “good homes” are sending the horses to auction once they get the money.
content: In a lifetime of working with horses, Gary Kidd, 73, had never adopted an untrained wild mustang before. But when the federal government started paying people $1,000 a horse to adopt them, he signed up for as many as he could get. So did his wife, two grown daughters and a son-in-law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Rombauer Wins the Preakness, Surging as Medina Spirit Fades to Third
description: The long-shot win assured that Bob Baffert’s colt could not claim a Triple Crown under the cloud of a positive drug test.
content: BALTIMORE — Medina Spirit was running against more than the nine rivals on the track on Saturday. He was taking on an ex-president who had called him “a junkie,” late-night comics and a public skeptical of his natural talent after he won the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago but failed a drug test afterward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: A Shot in the Dark
description: Joe DiPietro’s Sunday puzzle is shrouded in mystery.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Joe DiPietro is a Brooklynite and a publican; his current New York City bar, in Chelsea, is called “One Star,” and he once owned No Idea, the bar you would go to when nobody in your group had the energy to make a decision. I’m hoping he might open some kind of night school for patrons rather than bartenders, where we can all go to practice talking to groups of people and making eye contact again — someone’s bound to do this, right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Paulina Porizkova, Full-Frontal Emotion
description: The veteran supermodel is contesting the will of her late husband, Ric Ocasek — and writing herself a splashy new chapter.
content: When the writer and model Paulina Porizkova was asked by Aaron Sorkin to join him at the Oscars for what would be their second real date, she hesitated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bob Koester, Revered Figure in Jazz and Blues, Dies at 88
description: Mr. Koester’s Delmark Records and his Chicago record store were vital in preserving and promoting music the big labels tended to overlook.
content: Bob Koester, who founded the influential Chicago blues and jazz label Delmark Records and was also the proprietor of an equally influential record store where players and fans mingled as they sought out new and vintage sounds, died on Wednesday at a care center in Evanston, Ill., near his home in Chicago. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Shootings in New York spiked during the pandemic, and may outlast the virus.
description: As of the second weekend in May, New York City had recorded 505 shooting victims, the most through that point of any year in the last decade.
content: As of the second weekend in May, New York City had recorded 505 shooting victims, the most through that point of any year in the last decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Mask? No Mask? New Rules Leave Americans Recalibrating, Hour by Hour
description: The C.D.C. said fully vaccinated people could safely go most places without a mask. Not everyone was sure, or ready.
content: CHICAGO — For Americans whose bare faces had scarcely been seen in public for a year, there were suddenly options. Would they leave the mask behind for a jog? What about the coffee shop? What about the neighbor’s house? The office?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Medina Spirit and Horse Racing’s Deadly Drug Scandals
description: New laws cleaning up the sport of horse racing can’t come soon enough.
content: On May 1, Medina Spirit, a horse trained by Bob Baffert, one of the stars of thoroughbred racing, somewhat unexpectedly won the Kentucky Derby. About a week later, it emerged that the horse had tested positive for an anti-inflammatory pain-masking drug, throwing his victory into question. Mr. Baffert has been suspended by Churchill Downs, and the horse will most likely lose his win if a second sample confirms the first finding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien and Hikari Hida
title: Taiwan hits a daily case record.
description: The self-governing island, which has had striking success with the virus, ramped up restrictions in Taipei after reporting 180 locally transmitted infections.
content: Taiwan, which has had remarkable success in containing the coronavirus, raised restrictions for its main city to their highest level since the start of the pandemic on Saturday, after reporting a daily record of 180 new locally transmitted infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Vivian Yee
title: Conflict Spirals Across Israel and the Palestinian Territories
description: An American envoy landed in Israel for cease-fire talks with Palestinians and Israelis. But as of Saturday evening, there was no sign of a letup in fighting and a media center in Gaza was destroyed.
content: JERUSALEM — Fighting between Israelis and Palestinians spiraled across several fronts on Saturday as Israel destroyed a high-rise building in Gaza housing the offices of two major international media outlets, thousands of Palestinians fled their homes, Hamas militants in Gaza fired more rocket barrages toward the Tel Aviv area, and protests broke out again in the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Craft projects and gospel choirs.
content: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: At 18, He Had Consensual Sex With 2 Teens. Montana Wants Him to Stay a Registered Offender.
description: A federal judge said Randall Menges should be removed from a sex-offender registry, but the Montana attorney general plans to fight to keep him on it.
content: In 1993, when he was 18, Randall Menges had consensual sex with two other teenage boys at a camp in Idaho.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Bake Something!
description: This weekend, give a new baking project a go: One-bowl carrot cake or no-knead bread are perfect options.
content: The weekend has arrived. What are you baking? How about Genevieve Ko’s one-bowl carrot cake (above), with its slightly burnished and caramelized cream cheese topping? Or J. Kenji López-Alt’s updated take on the Jim Lahey’s renowned no-knead bread? Perhaps the latest from Dorie Greenspan would entice, a casual gâteau Basque that is equal parts crumbly, tender and chewy. If you’d rather eat something savory, look no further than our most popular recipe of the week: chile-roasted chicken with honey, lemon and feta from Melissa Clark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: In some U.S. counties, nearly all people over 65 are vaccinated.
description: The proportion of those with full protection is much higher among older Americans than among younger people.
content: More than 70 percent of Americans who are 65 or older are fully vaccinated, and 84 percent have received at least one dose, a much higher proportion than for younger Americans, according to federal data. The numbers have surpassed President Biden’s goal of at least partly vaccinating 70 percent of the nation’s adults by July 4.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Here’s how to watch the Preakness.
description: These are the morning-line odds for the 146th running of the race.
content: Coverage of the 146th Preakness Stakes began on NBC Sports Network at 2 p.m. Eastern time and moves to NBC at 5 p.m. Coverage will also be streamed on NBC Sports Live. Post time for the mile and three-sixteenths race is 6:57 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: What We Can Learn From Fearless Girls
description: Afghanistan shows that change comes through teachers as well as troops.
content: Lying in her hospital bed in Kabul, Afghanistan, having survived an extremist group’s bombing that killed more than 80 students at her school, a 17-year-old named Arifa was as determined as she was frightened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: An Everest expedition abandons base camp after several climbers test positive for the coronavirus.
description: Anyone who becomes infected “at high altitude, then develops symptoms and becomes ill, is very difficult to help,” a climbing company official said.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — A prominent mountaineering company abandoned its expedition to Mount Everest, dismantling its tents at base camp on Saturday after members of its team tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman, Apoorva Mandavilli, Rebecca Robbins and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: What Would It Take to Vaccinate the World Against Covid?
description: When President Biden joined a push to set aside patents for Covid shots, he entered a roiling debate over how to ensure poor countries get enough vaccine.
content: In delivering vaccines, pharmaceutical companies aided by monumental government investments have given humanity a miraculous shot at liberation from the worst pandemic in a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: G.O.P. Pursues Harsher Penalties for Poll Workers in Voting Crackdown
description: Heavy fines, felony charges and jail sentences: Republicans seeking to restrict voting are proposing strict punishments for election officials and workers who make errors or violate the rules.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Anita Phillips has been an election judge in Texas for 17 years, responsible for managing a precinct in Waco, a city of roughly 135,000 people. But over the last four years, the civic duty she prized has become arduous. Harassment by partisan poll watchers has grown increasingly caustic, she has found, and helping voters is ever more treacherous amid a thicket of new rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: University of California Will No Longer Consider SAT and ACT Scores
description: The university system has reached a settlement with students to scrap even optional testing from admissions and scholarship decisions.
content: The University of California will not take SAT and ACT scores into account in admissions or scholarship decisions for its system of 10 schools, which include some of the nation’s most sought-after campuses, in accordance with a settlement in a lawsuit brought by students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: When Students Shared Their Struggles, They Helped Me With My Own
description: Reporting on the impact of the pandemic, I had hoped to gain a deeper understanding of teenagers’ pain. But I received much more than that.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: We know Medina Spirit, but what about Bob Baffert’s other horse?
description: Derby controversy aside, a victory from either Medina Spirit or Concert Tour would give Baffert a record eight victories in the Preakness.
content: The world knows about Medina Spirit by now: the gritty Derby victory, the failed drug test and a long wait to see if the colt would be disqualified. But what about Baffert’s other horse in the Preakness?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi and David Zucchino
title: A Fragile Ceasefire Lets Afghans Risk Travel for Eid
description: A 3-day cease-fire is violated, but Afghans brave dangerous roads to celebrate a holiday with families.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — On Saturday, the final day of a three-day national cease-fire for Eid al-Fitr, the three-day Muslim celebration marking the end of fasting after the holy month of Ramadan, the killings in Afghanistan kept coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Violence Shakes Trump’s Boast of ‘New Middle East’
description: Trump officials said the Abraham Accords between Israel and four Arab states would transform the region, but new Israeli-Palestinian clashes lay bare the limits of that change.
content: WASHINGTON — It was, President Donald J. Trump proclaimed in September, “the dawn of a new Middle East.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Your Questions About Vaccines at Work, Answered
description: The rules for keeping workers safe can be difficult to navigate.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What TikTok Stars Owe ‘The Ellen DeGeneres Show’
description: The comedian is ending her daytime talk show after 19 years. Her segment “Ellen’s Wonderful Web of Wonderment” was the start of a new kind of fame.
content: In May 2010, well before the TikTok era, a 12-year-old from Oklahoma named Greyson Chance was summoned to “The Ellen DeGeneres Show.” A couple of weeks earlier, Greyson had found early viral fame after he posted his middle school talent show performance of Lady Gaga’s “Paparazzi” on YouTube. When Greyson came on the show, where he sat in a plush chair directly across from the daytime star and discussed his Gaga cover, the YouTube video had a million page views.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee, Lara Jakes and David M. Halbfinger
title: As Biden reaches out, Netanyahu vows attacks until Israel’s security is ensured.
description: President Biden spoke to the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians. Hamas militants aimed another round of rockets at Tel Aviv and protests spread to the West Bank.
content: The violence in Gaza entered a seventh consecutive day on Sunday, hours after President Biden spoke to the Israeli and Palestinian leaders and protests erupted anew in the occupied West Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina
title: Tensions Among Democrats Grow Over Israel as the Left Defends Palestinians
description: Divisions within the party have burst into public view, with the party’s ascendant left viewing the Mideast conflict as a searing racial justice issue that carries echoes of U.S. politics.
content: In 1988, when James Zogby, the founder of the Arab American Institute, pushed Democrats to include a mention of Palestinian sovereignty in their platform, party leaders responded with a clear warning, he recalled: “If the P-word is even in the platform, all hell will break loose.” Eager to stave off an angry confrontation at the convention, the issue was shelved without a vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Hacked Pipeline Is Now Delivering ‘Millions of Gallons’ an Hour, Owner Says
description: But it will still take days for gas stations in the Southeast to restock after panic buying depleted their supplies.
content: HOUSTON — The Colonial Pipeline, which delivers nearly half the transportation fuel to the Southeast and New York area, resumed full operations on Saturday, eight days after it was shut down by a ransomware attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Gallagher
title: Leigh Perkins, Who Built Orvis Into a Lifestyle Brand, Dies at 93
description: In 28 years at the company’s helm, he turned a small mail-order fishing tackle shop into a sporting brand with stores all over the country.
content: Leigh H. Perkins, who built Orvis from a modest mail-order fishing tackle shop in Manchester, Vt., into one of America’s largest and most distinctive sporting lifestyle brands, with stores all over the country, died on May 7 at his home in Monticello, Fla. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Meier
title: Secret Sharers: The Hidden Ties Between Private Spies and Journalists
description: A booming, renegade private intelligence industry is increasingly shaping (and misshaping) the news.
content: Some journalists are happy to knock on the doors of strangers. I was never one of them, but Christopher Steele, the ex-British spy behind the infamous Trump dossier, left me no choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael LaForgia and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: How a Genetic Trait in Black People Can Give the Police Cover
description: Sickle cell trait has been cited in dozens of police custody deaths ruled accidental or natural, even though the condition is benign on its own, a Times investigation found.
content: When they carried the body of a 32-year-old Black man named Lamont Perry out of the woods in Wadesboro, N.C., there were no protests over his sudden death in police custody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Kevin Quealy and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: 723 Epidemiologists on When and How the U.S. Can Fully Return to Normal
description: Government mandates are lifting, but these experts say the pandemic won’t really end nationally until more people, including children, are vaccinated.
content: Covid-19 cases are decreasing in the United States, and masks are no longer required everywhere, but the pandemic is not over — and won’t be until younger children can also be vaccinated, epidemiologists said in a new survey by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Adam Rasgon, Iyad Abuheweila and Irit Pazner Garshowitz
title: An Israeli airstrike killed at least 10 members of a family in a Gaza refugee camp.
description: An Israeli airstrike that hit a house in a Gaza refugee camp killed at least 10 Palestinians from the same extended family overnight, eight of them children, according to witnesses. A 5-month-old infant was pulled from the rubble alive.
content: An Israeli airstrike that hit a house in a Gaza refugee camp killed at least 10 Palestinians from the same extended family overnight, eight of them children, according to witnesses. A 5-month-old infant was pulled from the rubble alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Fall Guy
description: Andrea Pirlo was given a difficult task and failed at it. But if Juventus misses out on next season’s Champions League, it won’t be entirely his fault.
content: The jokes almost wrote themselves. Last summer, Juventus announced that it had installed Andrea Pirlo as coach of its under-23 team. It was a thoroughly sensible idea: the perfect place for a beloved former player to cut his teeth in a new phase of his career, the ideal spot for him to take his first job in management.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Damon Weaver, Child Reporter Who Interviewed Obama, Dies at 23
description: At 11 years old, Mr. Weaver gained national attention when he scored an interview with President Barack Obama, making him one of the youngest people to interview a sitting president.
content: Damon Weaver, who at age 11 became one of the youngest people to interview a sitting president and later gained attention for scoring other high-profile interviews with celebrities such as Dwyane Wade and Oprah Winfrey, died on May 1. He was 23.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: The infield party went on at the Preakness, if a bit muted.
description: Through the years restrictions have been added to curb rowdy behavior, and this year’s event may be the tamest of them all: Only about 3,000 people were allowed in the main part of the infield.
content: Stories about the infield party at the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore are legendary: the coolers of beer, the portable toilet races, the bikini contests, the couches brought in from the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Opinion
title: Young Americans, How Has George Floyd’s Death Influenced Your Life?
description: We want to hear from readers under 30 about their changing views of race and racism.
content: Darnella Frazier was just 17 when she recorded a video that shook the world. Her cellphone video, uploaded to Facebook, captured Derek Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd’s neck and upended the Minneapolis Police Department’s official narrative of the encounter, ultimately contributing to a guilty verdict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: New York Is Dead. Long Live New York.
description: What will happen to the city after the pandemic? Here are five scenarios to ponder.
content: “It’s a ghost town,” former President Donald J. Trump said of New York City last fall during a presidential debate. “It’s dying, everyone’s leaving New York.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Ivor Prickett
title: Syria’s Surprising Solar Boom: Sunlight Powers the Night in Rebel Idlib
description: Cut off from the power grid and with fuel costs soaring, Syrians in a poor, embattled enclave have turned en masse to solar panels to charge their phones and light their homes and tents.
content: HARANABUSH, Syria — When the Syrian government attacked their village, Radwan al-Shimali’s family hastily threw clothes, blankets and mattresses into their truck and sped off to begin new lives as refugees, leaving behind their house, farmland and television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece opens its doors to international tourists.
description: Greek television showed islanders on Mykonos, one of the country’s most popular summer destinations, painting cobblestone streets with whitewash in anticipation.
content: The first signs of the tourism season creeping back to life were visible at Greece’s ports and airports on Saturday as the country officially opened its doors to international visitors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: An annual day of Palestinian grievance comes amid the upheaval.
description: Nakba Day on Saturday denotes the 1948 displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians amid Israel’s declaration of independence.
content: The convulsions in Israel and the Palestinian territories were injected with an additional source of angry emotion on Saturday as the Palestinian diaspora and its supporters commemorated Nakba Day, denoting the 1948 displacement of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians amid Israel’s declaration of independence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Kids Will Be Kids, but Their Parents Should Know Better
description: A private lawn or patio is not a public playground, but some people need the obvious explained to them.
content: Q: I rent a ground-floor condo with a small patio in New Jersey. A family with two very young children recently moved into an adjacent building in the same complex. I often find the kids playing on my patio and looking into my apartment through a sliding door. There is no fence surrounding my patio, but it’s obvious that this is part of my private space. If their mother and I see each other outside, she shoos her boys away, but they keep coming back. Any suggestions for how to get them to play somewhere else, like the common lawn behind their building?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Stores, Parks and Restaurants Are Relaxing Their Mask Policies: Here’s the Latest
description: The new C.D.C. rules caught businesses by surprise, but in a matter of days, some moved to change their requirements.
content: Starbucks has joined a growing list of retailers, restaurants and theme parks that will now allow fully vaccinated customers to go mask free following new coronavirus safety guidance from the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Video Footage of Death of Black Man in South Carolina Jail Stirs Outrage
description: The death of Jamal Sutherland after officers tried to remove him from his cell using pepper spray and Tasers raised calls for changes in the treatment in custody of the mentally ill.
content: The death of a Black man after police used pepper spray and Tasers on him in a South Carolina jail has stirred outrage as well as widespread calls for changes to the treatment of people in custody suffering from mental illness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Accusers Are Subpoenaed as State Inquiry Enters a Critical Phase
description: Four women who have accused Gov. Andrew Cuomo of sexual misconduct have been formally asked to testify under oath.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Four women who have accused Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of sexual harassment have received subpoenas to testify under oath, the latest indication that the state attorney general’s investigation into Mr. Cuomo’s behavior has entered a critical phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Biden calls for protection of civilians and journalists in calls with Israel and Palestinian leaders.
description: President Biden backed Israel’s right to defend itself while urging the nation to protect civilians after the Israeli military destroyed a building housing the offices of journalists.
content: President Biden urged the leaders of Israel and the Palestinians to avoid additional deaths of children and other civilians in the escalating conflict on separate calls on Saturday and also affirmed his commitment to a two-state solution to bring peace in Jerusalem and elsewhere across Israel and the occupied territories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and Michelle Broder Van Dyke
title: A Police Shooting in Hawaii Has South Africans Demanding Justice
description: A Black man from South Africa was shot and killed in an encounter with the police in his adopted home, Hawaii. His countrymen want answers.
content: JOHANNESBURG — A plane from Honolulu landed in Johannesburg earlier this month and offloaded a plastic-wrapped coffin carrying the body of Lindani Myeni, a South African rugby player, aspiring singer and father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: The G.O.P.’s Big Cancellation
description: The party’s cancel mob runs wild on Capitol Hill.
content: Mr. Potato Head is under siege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Discovery of Bones From MOVE Bombing Jolts Philadelphia Once Again
description: City officials said that remains from the 1985 bombing, which were believed to have been cremated without the family’s permission, had apparently been saved in a box in storage.
content: The tortuous path of human remains from a deadly bombing that took place 36 years ago in Philadelphia took another jarring turn on Friday when city officials announced that bones they said had been cremated and discarded were apparently saved, after all, in a box in storage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The Mogul in Search of a Kinder, Gentler Capitalism
description: Lynn Forester de Rothschild, founder of the Coalition for Inclusive Capitalism, believes change will come when hedge fund billionaires and Pope Francis work together.
content: A self-made multimillionaire who married into a revered European banking dynasty, Lynn Forester de Rothschild now spends her time calling for higher taxes on the wealthy, stricter regulation of big business and a wholesale reordering of the capitalist system that has delivered her such privilege.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Tulsa Race Massacre Commission Ousts Oklahoma Governor
description: The 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre Centennial Commission removed Gov. Kevin Stitt from the panel just days after he had signed a bill that banned the teaching of certain concepts about race.
content: Gov. Kevin Stitt of Oklahoma has been ousted from a commission set up to commemorate the centennial of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, just days after he signed legislation that commission members said would undermine their goal of teaching the state’s painful history of racial discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Yitzhak Arad, Who Led Holocaust Study Center in Israel, Dies at 94
description: A survivor of the Nazis, Mr. Arad was an esteemed scholar and the longtime chairman of the Yad Vashem complex of museums and archives in Jerusalem.
content: Yitzhak Arad, who as an orphaned teenage partisan fought the Germans and their collaborators during World War II, then went on to become an esteemed scholar of the Holocaust and the longtime chairman of the Yad Vashem remembrance and research center in Israel, died on May 6 in a hospital in Tel Aviv. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Fans are back, but Preakness attendance is capped at 10,000.
description: Despite the latest C.D.C. guidance, masks were required when not eating and drinking at the Preakness, and “Covid compliance officers” were reminding guests to adhere to the policies.
content: The pandemic wreaked havoc on the Triple Crown schedule in 2020. The Belmont Stakes, normally the final leg of the Triple Crown, was held in New York in June, the Derby in September, and the Preakness, usually the second of the three races, came in October. None of them admitted spectators. This year, all have returned to their regular spots on the calendar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Should We Really Embrace ’90s Fashion?
description: A reader wonders about wearing 1990s trends today.
content: As far as I am concerned, when Harry Styles wore a yellow plaid Gucci blazer and lavender feather boa to perform at the Grammys in apparent homage to Alicia Silverstone’s character in “Clueless,” it was final proof (if any were needed) that the ’90s, that decade of grunge, slip dresses, knee socks, chokers, tracksuits and oversize blazers (well, hello, Balenciaga), were, as you say, back in fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Eula Hall, One-Woman Relief Agency in Appalachia, Dies at 93
description: Calling herself a “hillbilly activist,” she started a health care clinic and offered other services in chronically underserved eastern Kentucky.
content: Eula Hall was a tireless health care activist — so tireless that she wasn't about to let an arsonist slow her down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Sabrina Ionescu’s 3-Pointer Gives the Liberty a Season-Opening Win
description: In her Barclays Center debut, Ionescu finished with 25 points, 11 assists and 6 rebounds against the Indiana Fever.
content: Sabrina Ionescu made a 3-pointer from the wing with four tenths of a second left to give the Liberty a 90-87 victory over the Indiana Fever on Friday night in the W.N.B.A. season opener.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Army Wife, with Joel Rosario aboard, won the Black-Eyed Susan.
description: Army Wife won Friday’s marquee race for fillies at Pimlico, and Rosario will be aboard France Go de Ina in the Preakness.
content: Army Wife, ridden by Joel Rosario and trained by Mike Maker, won the Black-Eyed Susan Stakes on Friday at a sun-splashed Pimlico Race Course. Attendance was well below the stated capacity of 10,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: The sport is waiting for a second Medina Spirit test result. Why is it taking so long?
description: The wait could have set up an awkward situation if Medina Spirit had won the Preakness, the second leg of the Triple Crown.
content: Medina Spirit, who won the Kentucky Derby on May 1 to give the trainer Bob Baffert a record seventh victory in the race, was nearly excluded from the Preakness Stakes when it was disclosed that he had failed a drug test after the Derby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Radtke
title: Kristen Radtke Considers Another American Epidemic: Loneliness
description: The writer and artist spent nearly three years researching why so many of us feel so alone. What she found was much worse than she imagined.
content: I started writing about loneliness by accident. It seems too simple to say I wrote about loneliness because I was often lonely, although I was. It was 2016, during an election cycle that left many of us feeling wrenched from reality, and suddenly I was seeing loneliness everywhere. I’d walk down the street or step onto the subway during my morning commute and find that I couldn’t stop watching people who were physically alone: someone eating a sloppy gyro on the curb while staring blankly into space, an exhausted nurse still in her scrubs nodding off on the bus, the bodega cashier scrolling absently through his phone before a backdrop of condoms and Fritos pinned to the wall. There was nothing verifiably lonely about any of these people, and the fact that I identified loneliness in them said a lot more about me than it did them. I wanted to see their loneliness because I was feeling it myself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Fall River Ex-Mayor, Who Impressed Voters With His Zeal, Is Convicted of Corruption
description: Jasiel F. Correia II, who at 24 was the Massachusetts city’s youngest mayor, was convicted of charges related to extorting marijuana vendors and defrauding investors.
content: The former mayor of Fall River, Mass., who was elected at 23 after pitching himself as an ambitious entrepreneur and product of the city, was convicted by a federal jury on Friday of defrauding investors of more than $200,000 and extorting marijuana vendors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Dodd
title: Cicada Quiz: 17 Years Since Brood X and Bennifer. Remember When?
description: How much do you recall about 2004, the last time Brood X cicadas were mating and Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez were dating? Test your cultural memory here.
content: How much do you recall about 2004, the last time Brood X cicadas were mating and Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lopez were dating? Test your cultural memory here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weiyi Cai, Lazaro Gamio, Lauren Leatherby and Allison McCann
title: The Pandemic Has Split in Two
description: Zero deaths in some cities. Thousands in others. The pandemic’s fault lines continue to widen as vaccines flow toward rich countries.
content: Zero deaths in some cities. Thousands in others. The pandemic’s fault lines continue to widen as vaccines flow toward rich countries.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 15, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 15, 2021.
content: An article on March 29 about climate change and steel companies referred incompletely to the gases converted by bacteria into useful chemicals in pilot programs by ArcelorMittal. Both carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide are converted, not carbon dioxide alone.
source.name: The New York Times
